abstract: Masayoshi Son, the chief executive of Japan’s SoftBank Group, condemned the murder of the journalist Jamal Khashoggi but added that “we cannot turn our backs on the Saudi people.”

headline: Alibaba Feels the Pinch From China’s Slowing Economic Growth
abstract: The e-commerce giant lowered its estimate for revenue growth this year as challenges mount for the world’s second largest economy.

headline: A South African Take on the Vision Fund May Be Small, but It Carries No Saudi Baggage
abstract: As the global investment spotlight illuminated Riyadh last month, Naspers unveiled plans to pour $315 million into South African tech start-ups.

headline: Belgians Open Homes, and Hearts, to Migrants
abstract: Thousands of Belgians, angry with government policy, are volunteering to feed and house asylum seekers. “I feel ashamed of my country,” one says.

headline: Netflix’s Audience Is Multiplying. But So Is Its Debt.
abstract: Netflix has enchanted subscribers and investors, and disrupted global media. But its dependence on debt raises questions about its real value.

headline: Fox Executive Condemns Remarks by Guest on Lou Dobbs Show
abstract: The show was originally shown on Thursday. But the remarks, which were linked to anti-Semitism, created a firestorm online when the show was shown again on Saturday.

headline: U.S. Hunter Kills ‘Beautiful’ Goat. Now Scotland Is Scrutinizing Its Laws.
abstract: Larysa Switlyk’s Instagram image of the carcass with the words “fun hunt!!” drew condemnation on social media, including from the mother of the Scottish tennis star Andy Murray.

headline: Shinzo Abe Says Japan Is China’s ‘Partner,’ and No Longer Its Aid Donor
abstract: For 40 years, Japan has quietly given foreign aid to China. Visiting Beijing, its leader said that would end, announcing a “new phase” in the relationship.

headline: IBM to Buy Red Hat, the Top Linux Distributor, for $34 Billion
abstract: The deal is a big move to bring more software developers under IBM’s wing and hints at a bigger push into cloud computing.

headline: They Escaped China’s Crackdown, but Now Wait in Limbo
abstract: An ethnic Uighur Muslim family’s struggle to stay in Sweden illustrates the risks for a people whose plight, until recently, had received little attention.

headline: ‘They Threw Themselves Into the Sea, 14 Black Women, All Together’
abstract: Nantes played a major role in the European slave trade. Its museum and memorial are a model for other French cities grappling with their histories.

headline: Bishops Urge Greater Inclusion of Women in Church Decisions
abstract: A Vatican document presented to the pope says that the church needs ideas and more women in decision-making roles.

headline: Sri Lanka’s President Suspends Parliament, Escalating Political Crisis
abstract: Having already sworn in a new prime minister, President Mathripala Sirisena is now trying to shore up support for the move. Some officials have denounced the change as illegal.

headline: As Merkel Weakens, One German Election Takes On New Importance
abstract: Germans in Hesse will elect a new government on Sunday, but all eyes will be on what the outcome will mean for Angela Merkel’s government in Berlin.

headline: Vatican Mum on North Korea’s Invitation to Pope Francis
abstract: No pope has ever visited North Korea, although Francis has repeatedly called for reconciliation on the peninsula.

headline: Queensland Becomes Latest Australian State to Decriminalize Abortion
abstract: After days of emotional debate, lawmakers overturned an 1899 law that made abortion a criminal offense. “History has been made,” the premier said.

headline: Australian Leader Considers Moving Embassy to Jerusalem From Tel Aviv
abstract: Prime Minister Scott Morrison echoed many of the points President Trump gave for a similar decision. The announcement drew criticism as a political gambit to win a local election.

headline: Steady Hands at the Treasury and the Fed Comfort Investors
abstract: Neither the Treasury Department nor the central bank have so far been swayed by President Trump’s views on some serious issues.

headline: China Imposes Record Fine on Vaccine Maker Over Safety Scandal
abstract: The penalty, of $1.3 billion, comes at a time of increasing anxieties among the country’s middle class, already furious about a spate of drug and food safety scandals.

headline: Tesla Faces a Challenger in the Home Solar Business
abstract: Tesla is relying on showrooms to sell electric cars, solar roofs and batteries. But a California rival has made inroads into the residential business.

headline: Unraveling a Tesla Mystery: Lots (and Lots) of Parked Cars
abstract: Groups of new vehicles are being detected in unexplained locations across the country. Evidence being posted online has raised questions about production, logistics, quality and even demand.

headline: CBS Inquiry Into What Went Wrong in Les Moonves Era Hits Snags as It Advances
abstract: Investigators have interviewed more than 250 people as they examine allegations of misconduct. But not every accuser has been contacted, and some are hesitant to cooperate.

headline: Mexico’s Incoming President Plans to Cancel Giant New Airport Project
abstract: The president-elect will halt construction of a $13 billion airport that is already under construction, prompting protests from the business community and investors.

headline: In Moscow, an Emotional Assembly to Remember the Victims of Stalin’s Terror
abstract: An annual memorial proceeded after officials backed down from a decision to bar it from its traditional site, near the headquarters of the former KGB.

headline: Rescue Workers Search for Missing After Typhoon Strikes Philippines
abstract: Nine bodies were recovered Wednesday from the site of a government building that was buried by a landslide after Typhoon Yutu struck the country’s north.

headline: China Mocks Report It Tapped Trump’s iPhone (and Plugs Its Own Competitor)
abstract: China ridiculed but did not explicitly deny reports by intelligence officials that the Chinese tapped President Trump’s phone calls with old friends.

headline: Rights Prize Goes to Oleg Sentsov, a Russian Prisoner, in a Rebuke to Putin
abstract: The European Parliament awarded Mr. Sentsov, a Ukrainian filmmaker imprisoned in Russia, the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought.

headline: Cathay Pacific Data Breach Exposes 9.4 Million Passengers
abstract: The Hong Kong-based carrier said that people’s passport data and travel histories were among the information that was compromised in the incident.

headline: Despite Weak Spots, E.U. Economy Is Not Nearing Recession, Mario Draghi Says
abstract: Mr. Draghi, president of the European Central Bank, said the eurozone economy is still solid and that Rome and Brussels will work out their issues.

headline: Turbocharging Jumps From Racetrack to Cul-de-Sac
abstract: Industry experts expect that by 2027, more than half the vehicles sold in the United States will include turbo power.

headline: Apple iPhone XR Review: A Cheaper Phone Suited to Most of Us
abstract: In an era of skyrocketing smartphone prices, it’s a relief that Apple’s $750 iPhone is just as powerful and nearly as capable as its $1,000 counterparts, our reviewer found.

headline: This Thermometer Tells Your Temperature, Then Tells Firms Where to Advertise
abstract: Clorox is using data from so-called smart thermometers to target ads to areas where people are sick. It’s the latest example of internet-connected devices being used for advertising.

headline: In Final Column, Jamal Khashoggi Laments Dearth of Free Press in Arab World
abstract: The Washington Post received the prominent Saudi dissident journalist’s latest piece from his translator the day after he was reported missing in Istanbul.

headline: Pakistan Tries a New Way to Pay for a Dam: Crowdsourcing
abstract: The financially challenged government asks Pakistanis at home and abroad to donate to a $14 billion dam project. It’s a sign of a much bigger problem.

headline: What Comes After the Roomba?
abstract: The Roomba cleaned floors, and it was a hit. But though many have tried to perfect the next version of a home robot, no one has succeeded yet.

headline: Palestinian Leaders Are Accused of Using Torture and Arbitrary Arrests to Crush Dissent
abstract: The advocacy group Human Rights Watch said the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank and Hamas in Gaza had turned their territories into “police states.”

headline: Smoking Marijuana Is Legal in Canada, Unless You’re South Korean
abstract: South Koreans are still subject to their country’s strict drug laws even when abroad, and can face up to five years in prison upon their return.

headline: Megyn Kelly Apologizes to NBC Colleagues Amid Storm Over ‘Blackface’ Remarks
abstract: While discussing how “the costume police are cracking down” this Halloween, the NBC morning host defended ways of dressing up that offend others.

headline: Google Is Teaching Children How to Act Online. Is It the Best Role Model?
abstract: The tech giant is positioning itself in schools as a trusted authority on digital citizenship at a moment when the company’s data-handling practices are under growing scrutiny.

headline: They Said Seattle’s Higher Base Pay Would Hurt Workers. Why Did They Flip?
abstract: Researchers whose findings last year pointed to a downside from raising the minimum wage have taken another look and the reality is more nuanced.

headline: Taiwan Train Accident Kills at Least 18 and Injures About 170 Others
abstract: The train derailed in Yilan County, in the northeast. More than 360 people were on board the coastal Puyuma Express train, the fastest in eastern Taiwan.

headline: In Poland Elections, Populists Fail to Sway Moderates, Exit Polls Suggest
abstract: Although official results are not yet in, exit polls suggested that the governing Law and Justice party had not expanded its appeal to the moderates in Poland’s urban areas.

headline: Jordan Reclaims Lands Used by Israel Under Peace Treaty
abstract: Under internal political pressure, King Abdullah II of Jordan said he was reversing a clause of the 1994 treaty that symbolized the peace with Israel.

headline: Few Big Names Expected at Saudi Conference, and Data on U.S. Economy
abstract: Several tech companies report earnings, including Amazon and Alphabet. The European Central Bank will discuss monetary policy.

headline: Fox Network Is Replacing Chief With Charlie Collier of AMC
abstract: Gary Newman, a co-chief executive of the Fox Television Group, had been expected to stay in charge, but wanted to leave in the spring. So the network acted now.

headline: Republicans Find a Facebook Workaround: Their Own Apps
abstract: Conservative political apps deliver curated partisan messages, free from the strictures and content guidelines imposed by Silicon Valley giants.

headline: Japan and China, Asian Rivals, Are Trying to Get Along
abstract: Shinzo Abe’s state visit to China this week will be the first by a Japanese leader in eight years. Both sides are seeking a little normality in the age of Trump.

headline: Leading an Active Life With a Diagnosis of Dementia
abstract: As the number of people with dementia rises, those with early stages of the ailment are pursuing fulfilling lives and making plans for future care.

headline: An Alternative to Saudi Funds Might Lie in Qatar
abstract: The tiny peninsula country has plenty of natural-resource wealth and more enlightened social policies than its neighbor.

headline: Security Images Show Khashoggi and Fiancée in His Final Hours
abstract: The images were published by the Turkish media as part of the continuing leaks from the investigation into the journalist’s death inside the Saudi Consulate.

headline: Australia’s Other Great (and Threatened) Coral Reefs
abstract: Every one of Australia’s coral reefs is threatened by climate change, potentially devastating not just the country’s ecosystems but its economy as well.

headline: Stocks Resume Slide, Pulling S.&P. 500 Briefly Into a Correction
abstract: The benchmark index fell to 10 percent off its most recent peak in early trading on Friday but recovered some of those losses. It is down more than 9 percent from its high in September.

headline: Migrants Reach a Crossroads in Mexico, Far From the Raging Debate
abstract: Although President Trump said he may seal the southwest border to all migrants, the revelation barely registered among the determined migrants.

headline: Another Tax Cut? Trump and Republicans Offer a Midterm Pitch, if Not a Plan
abstract: Although the president promised to soon roll out “a very major tax cut” for middle-income Americans, such a proposal has no chance of passing before the midterms.

headline: Misery ‘Every Day, Every Hour’ in Syrian Camp. And Now, It’s Grown Critical.
abstract: The humanitarian situation for some 50,000 Syrians at a camp for the displaced near the Jordanian border has deteriorated, and aid agencies warn it has reached a critical level.

headline: Trump’s Trade War May Create New Auto Jobs. In China.
abstract: Caught in a crossfire of tariffs, BMW and other foreign carmakers are gauging whether to relocate some manufacturing to China. Jobs could follow.

headline: Campaign Contribution Raises Concerns About China’s Meddling in New Zealand
abstract: One New Zealand lawmaker has accused another of trying to disguise a campaign contribution from a businessman with ties to the Chinese Communist Party.

headline: Shanghai Is Being Thrust Into the High-Stakes Tech I.P.O. Race
abstract: China will test a looser U.S.-style system for new listings in Shanghai. It’s an overdue reform, but officials may rue the volatility it could bring.

headline: A ‘Legacy of Terror’: ISIS Left More Than 200 Mass Graves in Iraq
abstract: It may not be much of a surprise, but the scale of the job of digging up Islamic State victims is shocking. The UN says there may be 12,000 victims.

headline: Pakistani Court Acquits Christian Woman in Capital Blasphemy Case
abstract: Asia Bibi had been on death row for eight years, and her case helped focus international attention on Pakistan’s harsh blasphemy law.

headline: Why a Nestlé Skin Care Unit Is Attractive to Private Equity
abstract: Rival consumer groups may be put off by the business’s products and low margins, but private equity firms have recently shown interest in dermatology.

headline: The Mad Dash to Find a Cybersecurity Force
abstract: Employers and educators are rethinking the way they attract and train potential employees to meet the demands of an increasingly vulnerable online world.

headline: Fact-Checking Trump’s Claims About the Chinese Economy
abstract: At a news conference, the president answered a question about healing national divides by saying, falsely, that he had forced China to back down from a plan to strengthen its manufacturing industry.

headline: France’s Mayors, Feeling the Pinch, Lead a Quiet Rebellion and Quit
abstract: More than 150 rural mayors have left this year, saying they feel abandoned by the state in the face of shrinking revenues, declining populations and reforms initiated by President Emmanuel Macron.

headline: Poland’s Leaders March With Far-Right Groups on Independence Day
abstract: The president said the 100th anniversary of Polish independence was “for everyone.” The march included the far right and omitted opposition leaders.

headline: Mexico Gave the Migrant Caravan a Warm Welcome. It Wasn’t Always This Way.
abstract: A caravan of Central American migrants has left Mexico City, bound for the U.S. border. The group has forced a reckoning in Mexico over the treatment of migrants.

headline: Are You Ready for the Nanoinfluencers?
abstract: Influencers are so 2014. And microinfluencers are so last week. Now advertisers see value in people with as few as 1,000 followers: the nanoinfluencers.

headline: OPEC, Russia Weigh Production Cuts to Prop Up Oil Prices
abstract: Oil ministers warned that the gap between supply and demand could widen next year, which “may require new strategies to balance the market.”

headline: The Election Showed a Divided Country. Investors Can Live With That.
abstract: The S&P 500 has risen in four of the first five trading days of the November. Wednesday’s 2.1 percent gain was its third-best showing this year.

headline: Philippine Lawyer Who Resisted Duterte’s Drug War Is Gunned Down
abstract: The lawyer, Benjamin Ramos, was shot by men on a motorcycle after being put on a watchlist by the police and military.

headline: A Flashy Qatari Deal Hints at the Nation’s New Investment Style
abstract: The Gulf state’s wealth fund is under new management, and looks to be prioritizing the acquisition of trophy assets.

headline: Macron Hopes WWI Ceremonies Warn of Nationalism’s Dangers. Is Anyone Listening?
abstract: Emmanuel Macron, the French president, hoped his carefully orchestrated centennial of the Armistice would bolster his vision for “more Europe.” But it may underscore his increasing isolation.

headline: Cost of Botched Gaza Spy Mission? Israel’s Back on Brink of War
abstract: Israel and Hamas exchanged intense fire after a covert Israeli operation went awry. The resulting fighting threatened to scuttle peace talks.

headline: Australia’s Prime Minister ‘Surprised’ by State’s Secret Deal With China
abstract: The state of Victoria signed on with China’s Belt and Road initiative at a time when intelligence officials are concerned about Beijing’s influence.

headline: In Prison for 16 Years, and Still Waiting for a Verdict
abstract: The case of Daniel García, charged with murder, exemplifies many flaws of Mexico’s old justice system. An overhaul of the system has helped others — but not him.

headline: With Early Israel Elections, Netanyahu Banks on Strengthening Support
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, facing possible bribery charges, had wanted his government to complete its term through next November. He changed his mind.

headline: Erdogan Presses for Answers From Saudi Prince in Khashoggi Killing
abstract: The Turkish president expressed frustration to reporters, saying the de facto leader of Saudi Arabia had done nothing to expose the truth about the dissident’s death.

headline: WeWork’s Rise: How a Sublet Start-Up Is Taking Over
abstract: Critics have derided WeWork as overvalued and vulnerable to the next downturn. But the company holds so many leases in so many cities, it might hold more power than its landlords.

headline: Historic Preservation or Just Ripping Out a Way of Life in Beijing?
abstract: A renovation campaign in Beijing’s historic neighborhoods has left a tear in the fabric of urban life. Preservationists, and local residents, are ambivalent about the results.

headline: Pakistani Christian Freed After Being Cleared in Blasphemy Case
abstract: Asia Bibi, who had been on death row for eight years, was released from a women’s prison in central Pakistan and flown to Islamabad late Wednesday.

headline: Senator Urges Trump to Ease Ban on Aid Workers Traveling to North Korea
abstract: Senator Edward J. Markey praised President Trump’s attempt at diplomacy with the North but also said that “the humanitarian situation in North Korea is far too dire for these draconian policies.”

headline: Facebook Thwarted Chaos on Election Day. It’s Hardly Clear That Will Last.
abstract: Facebook made strides toward cleaning up its service in the last two years. But it continues to behave most responsibly only when placed under a microscope.

headline: Russian Trolls Were at It Again Before Midterms, Facebook Says
abstract: The company said Tuesday that it had taken down more than 100 Facebook and Instagram accounts linked to the Internet Research Agency, a troll farm.

headline: Trudeau Apologizes for Canada’s Turning Away Ship of Jews Fleeing Nazis
abstract: In 1939, Canada refused desperate pleas for asylum by the captain of the St. Louis, a ship with more than 900 passengers. Most were Jews fleeing Germany.

headline: That’s a Lot of Lamps: 300,000 Lit in India for Diwali, Breaking Record
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of lamps illuminated the northern city of Ayodhya for Diwali, casting a glowing light over the city. But there was concern that the spectacle could contribute to air pollution.

headline: Red-Hot Economy? Women Aren’t Convinced
abstract: A remarkable gender gap, transcending party lines, has opened up in Americans’ views of both their own finances and the broader national economy.

headline: Parts of America Are Still Struggling Economically. They Don’t Matter Much in the Midterms.
abstract: The most competitive districts in the race for control of the House are disproportionately prosperous — and their economies aren’t doing much to lift Republicans.

headline: A Tale of Two Washingtons Awaits Wall Street Banks
abstract: The Federal Reserve wants to relax rules for the biggest banks, but Democrats, who will take control of the House next year, say they plan to keep banks on a tight leash.

headline: The Economy Didn’t Save Republicans After All
abstract: Neither strong growth nor a $1.5 trillion tax cut helped President Trump’s party in the midterm elections — by any number of measures.

headline: Your Office Doesn’t Have Nap Time Because You Are Not a Child
abstract: Being a grown-up means being responsible for your choices. Like many grown-ups, you can also decide you don’t need to care.
